div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,141] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, MARCH 7, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are intended to leave Port Baid on or about the following dates:
Port-Said to London Via Brindisi
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails. Combined steamer and sleeping care fair from Port-Said to london via Brindisi or via Marseiles.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Suez about March 10
R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about March 24.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Port Said about March 18
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about March 27th
N.B.- Homward steamers are sometimes before shels advertised daies,
Passengers landed and embarked at Ismailia, Quearantine Regulations permitting, free of all expenses.
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,966 tons, leaves about March 16.
S.S. Chershore 5,708 tons, leaves about March 30.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about March 6.
S.S. Shropshire 5,220 tons leaves about March 20.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Fitted with Refridgerators, Electric Light, Electric fans, and all recent improvements.
Experienced Stweardesse and Surgeons carried - Agents in Cairo, Messre Thod, Cook & Son.
For all particuars apply to W. Stapledon & Son, Port-Said & Port-Tawfik (Suez)
Note. – The outward Bibby willhenceforth leave suex one day later than before.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.

Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels
div.p: Cataract Hotel, Assounan

This most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the addition of 65 rooms and accomodates 360 guests. Grand dining hall, life, tennis court, and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billard room and bar., Electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel Assouan.- Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accomodates 80 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beautiful Terrance overlooking river. Electric lights throughout.

div.head: Grand Hotel, Khartoum
div.p: Standing in a magnificent position in its own grounds on the high banks of the Blue Nile.
Elegantly Furnished: Every comfort and convenience; through connection with London; perfect climate; lovely gardens; excellent cuisine - Wire Manager, Hotel, Khartoum.

div.head: Grand Hotel Helouan.
div.p: Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate Charges.- Special terms for residents. Golf Links (18 Holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the desert.

Sulphur Bath Establishment-Sulpher Water Shtronger than any in Europe. Right European measures and Masseuses. Every Modern Improvement.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN CRISIS.
div.p: As banal, there are two sitnations in
Russian affairs to be watched with the closest
interest, the sitnation at home and the situa-
tion at the front Both have now become
just about as bad as they could possibly
be, and our interest has beonme positively
morbid. To watch the telegraph for the nut
news from St Petersburg, the provinces, or
Manohuria, gives something of the sensation
produced by watching an acrobat in a
national performance. But whereas we
pretty sure, ninety-nine timed out of a 1
dred, that the acrobat will not oome to u
we are equally sure that Russia must I
a grievous fall. Aid there is no net
break its force. Unless appearauoes are tot
deceptive, Kuropatkin and his army ai
tke most awkward position, and in fact
of this morning's telegrams goes so far a
declare that "the escape of thq Run
main force seams impossible.”
If the “formidable force of Japanese,” wl
it is feared, "is en route for Tieling,” ate.
its goal before the oomplete evacuatiui
Mukden, the position of General Kuropa
must be perilous in the extreme, and
heavy fighting to.the north west of Aiul
shows that the Russian retreat is iu dang;
being cut off. A telegram states that ‘a cm
expected on Monday or Tuesday,” but whe
this refers to the entire Russian Army we
not say. At any rate everything lends to s
(Hat the Russian defeat will iu a few In
become a disastrous rout, and it is not U
any attempt will be made to hold Mukden
efforts being concentrated on a desperate «t
at Tieling. The prospect does notseem aba
one for the Russiaus. Once disastrously ou
run, there is no reason to suppose that 1
, would do better at Tieling than elsewhere,
! we have yet to learn the exact whereabo
strength, and movements of the myster
force which has already got behiud the Kus
retreat, and may be astride the railway
tween Mukden and Tieling. In the autum
; was Sedan that was on our lips and in
minds. To-day it is Moscow. Even suppo
( that all was well in the camp, Kuropatl
danger would be great But if a tube of
rumours have - a foundation of fact, bis arm
neither in the mood nor the condition to t
such a fight as is belore it Ttie uieu, we 1
been told, are dispirited, mutinous, and I
starved. The officers, we know, are at sixes
sevens. No doubt Japan is hitting hard in i
of the possible arrangement of terms of pe
And it looks as if this latest battle m
modify considerably the» terms that Ku
might now obtain from a victorious enemy
Of oonrse the situation at the front and
situation at home are interdependent,
military position has been made more pi
rious and impossible by the insurrection wl
is now general, throughout Russia. Althc
the censor is still at work, aud we have
mere scraps of news sinoe Vladimir’s da}
Petersburg, the most pessimistic- of our I
casts are in the way of realisation. Short
a declared revolution things oould hardly
worse. Anarchy is rampaub Bailway <
munication has oeased on most lines.
Government are at their wit’s end, and
only advise local authorities to "do the
they can." ’Troops cannot be spared even
quell disturbances in the provinces. M
less oould they be spared to reinfi
Kuropatkin, even if they were in a n
for Manchurian fighting, aud even if tl
was any Mssibility—which there is not -
oonveyin \ them to the front The result
Russia ibeli aud the Russian Governmer
unoertaih. Out of the welter of chaos s<
new order aud system may emerge in ti
though imagination boggles at the probt
history of the intervening period. The re
for Kuropatfrin and his army is sure. Star
of supplies, oi men, of food, aud ammuuit
he finds himself isolated, out off from
distant base, thrown ou such resources as
country affords, and compelled to give ba
with dispirited troops and quarrelsome offi
to an enemy superior in numbers, equipnn
valour, and skill. It is not by the reoul
this battle or this campaign that his -niiiii
geuius can ever be truly judged.
Whether by the Tsar’s ownact or that of
people we may surely expect Russia to n
peace before long. There will be no other co<
open toher. Even were ourfriendRojdestvet
to sweep Togo from the sea—if—the use
reason of a naval viotory would be almost
troyed by the failure of the land cam]>s
Aud the "if’ is a singularly big one. Ha'
committed all the lollies — not forgetting
Dogger fight—that lunacy oould cram into
year of crowded life, the Russian Govern®
will be forced to oonclude such a peace as
pan may allow them. It will probably be «
another defeat and once more action will t
been takan several days too late. As with
ooncession of demands, so with the releav
Gorki, and so with the oonduct of the c
paign. Stupid blunders are made. No puq
is served by them, and the remedy com#
late. There is only one hope left for
friends of Russia—and we are not her fix
that the last tragedy of all may be avei
before the opportunity for that saving da
has gone with the rest,
j A 1[1] [2]S,N K A RING GOAL.
RUSSIANS UI-TUEATTNG IN
^ DISOUD1 R

St. Petehsburo, March 6. Kuropatkin reports that the advance guard i,f the Japaue.se who are surrounding his right think arrived on the 4th inst., from the direc­tion of Sin Alia-Ting, within 5 miles of Mukden ttatiou. ' . (Reuter./
London, March 6.

Reuter’s correspondent at Mukden cables ttiat the sudden appearance of Nogi's troops iroiu the direction ot Liao-llo aud Sin-Min- l’ing completely surprised, the Russians. The town was thrown into confusion. The streets ami-outlying roads are crowded with transports tind troops hastily assembling to oppose Nogi. It is ieared that a formidable force ol Japanese it eu route tor Tich-Lmg. (Reuter.)
Mukden, March 6.
The battle was renewed by Nogi during the afternoon of the 4tb inst., notwithstanding the terrible worn of the past three days, and that the troops had not tasted food for two days.
( Mentor.)
• Mukden, March 6.
The Japanese attacks on the trout of the Russian Airny continue, but they are repulsed. The struggle is becomiug desperate over a length of 120 versts. ' (Havas./
Tokio, March 6.
The Japanese left advance guard occupies a height four miles south of Mukden. (Havas./
London, March 6.

Reuter's correspondent at.Mukden, cabling last night, states ttiat the battle raged cease­lessly throughout the whole ol Sunday. The Japanese concentrated at Machiapu, south­west of Mukueu, but were unable to dislodge the Russians. -
Heavy bgbting has begun on the west aud nortn-wost of Musdeii, wnere Kuropatkiu has launched a ilc.-pciaw attack against the Japa­nese leit. The Kuaaiuus continue to hold tbe centre.r-

A continuous procession of trains and carts is leaving MukUcn, travelling northwards. A crisis is expected on Monday or Tuesday: Reuters correspouueut with General Oku reports that ou the 6ih lust, the Japanese left wing aUifliks, made since the 26 th ult., Were pushed home in the taco of tremendous diffi­culties aud neavy auuwaiorms. tstarahells and searchlights lighted up every uiuvenieut. They cartiea the^reuches, which wore defended by wire'eutangiemeuts aud briatling with machine guus, at the poiiit of the bayonet, despite the stubborn resistance uf the Kusaiaus. Tire latter are now retreating in disorder. The men are discarding their arms und clothing. The Japa­nese have captured a number of 6-iuch guus aud machine guns.

The attacks were covered by a most furioua bombardment. Alt the Tort Arthur siege guus were employed with terrible etlect, pulvensmg villages and earthworks aud demoralising tbe Russians, in the meantime, tbe lighting iu the ceutre was couiiueii to the artillery. The Japanese extreme lclt is now close to Mukden ou the north-west. The escape of the Russian main lorco seems impossible. (Reuter.
JAPANESE SQUADRONS.
SIGHTED SOUTH" OP HONG KONG.
London, March 6.
The "Daily Mail” learns from Hong-Kong that two Japauesc squadrons consisting ol twenty-two warships altogether, including battleships, have beeu sighted 100 miles south of that port. * (Reuter.j
PRINCE FERDINAND.
ON A VISIT TO THE KING.
London, March 6.
Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria has arrivec here on a visit to King Edward. (Reuter.,

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Khedive's Mariout Railway.—The broad- gauge line has already reached Amrieh,which is sixteen kilometres from Mex.
• Arafat*.”—This interesting Cairo Moslem journal, which has hitherto appeared weekly, has now become a monthly review.
IIelouan.— On the 10th inst, a grand ball will be given’bt the - Grand Hotel, Helouan, to which invitations may be had from the manager.
Sailors and Soldiers’ Institute.—Mission services by the Rev. F. B. N. Nonnan-I^e, S.C.F., will be held to-day and to-morrow at
6 p.m.
Sanitary Deft.—A credit of L.E. 3,500 has been opened for the Sauitary Adminis­tration for the construction of several annexes to the adminiatration’s offices.
Smokino Concert.—Tickets for the smok­ing concert to be given at Munferrato’s Hall on Saturday next by Mr. Scott-Leslie, assisted by several amateurs, may be had of Messrs. Davies Bryan & Go.
Suez Canal.—8 vessels passed through the
Cauai on the 3rd inst., 4 of which were British,
2 German, 1 Norwegian, 1 Portugese. The day’s
receipts were fra. 157,454.20, making the total
from the 1st inst. lrs. 1,039,074.59.

Army Inspections.— Major-General Slade, C.B., will inspect the Royal Garrison Artillery at the Citadel, Cairo, to-morrow at 9.30 a.m., aud the 1st Battalion Kiug’s Royal Ride Corps at Abbassieh on Thursday at 10 a.m.

Business Announcement.—Mr. Athanasius Samios begstoiniorm the public and his business relations that Mr Stephanos Samios retired from the Caty de la Bourse Khddiviale on the 7th ulto. and lias now no connection whatsoever with the business.

Ghkzirkh Palace.—On account of the fanoy dress ball to be held at the Casino of the Ghe- zireh Palace this evening, the usual small dauce will not take place at the Casino on Thursday next, when the grand garden ffite at Shep- heard’s will be held.

Dog Regulation?. — The new regulations concerning dogs drawn up by the Sauitary AilminisTfatiou are shortly to be referred to the Mixed Court ot Appeal, with a view to Uieir being rendered applicable to foreiguers as well as uatives. They will afterwards come Defore the Couucil of Ministers.

Agricultural Bank.—The Committee of the Louden Stock Excnange has ordered the undermentioned securities to be quoted iu tue Official List : Agricultural Rank of Egypt further issue of £626,000 3£ per cent. Bunds, 1924-1949, Nos. 32,426 to 35,550 ut £100, and 51,176 to 66,600 uf £20 each.

The Corporation of Western Eoypt(Ltd.) state that one half ol tbe corporation's share capital having been allotted, application was immediately made to the committee of the Loudon Stock Exchange to grant a special settlement in tho corporation’s shares,and that settlement was granted and effect given on the 16th ulto.

The Corso. — All the boxes for to-day’s Corse at Gnezireh Palace have been sold, and, it the weather uniy improves,’ large crowds are expected. As at February s bati|p of tiowers, peaestrions will cuter by the main gate of the Gnezireh Palace Hotel, while vehioles will drive round by the villas. To prevent any crowding the number uf "guichets” has beeu doubled.

Still They Come!—Tho tourist steamer ‘Arabic,” ol the White Star Line, hailing irum New York with 630 tourists on board, will arrive here tomorrow. The ‘‘Arabic” is of 15,601 tons displacement; length 600 ieet; breadth 65 J leot. She sailed from New fc’urk on February 2 and has called at Fun­chal, Cadiz, Gibraltar, Algiers, Malta, Pha- lerum, Coustautinuple, Smyrna, Caiffa aud Jail a, and proceeds heuce to Naples, Ville- tr^nche, rpool, and New York.

St. Catherine’s College.—A musical aud dramatic eutertaiumeut will be giveu at the college this afternoon. The programme in­cludes a comic opera in two acts entitled Le Moulin du Chat qai fume, by M. Ch. Le Roy-Villa re, and a musical extravag&hta in one act, The Happy Man, which has been adapted (and original songs introduced) by our talented fellow-townsman Mr. J. Pearce­ll ill, who has likewise painted the soehery for tbe production.

Mariout Causeway.— Owing to the increas­ing develop went of the Mariout district^ tht Causeway separating Lake Marootis from the salt lake, which is the only possible highway between Alexandria and Mariout, has become much too narrow for the traffic. Moreover, owing to the broadening of the railway gauge, there is very little space' even for a foot pas icuger. At this time of the year, wheu the dowers in the Manout district are in theii oeauty, many persons would like to ride ou! there, but in the present condition of tbe causeway it is dangerous, as one never knowt when a train carrying railway material'will appear on the causeway. The Publio Workt Department ought to undertake the broadening of this causeway in the interests both of the | Khedive and of tbe public .

div.head: STRANDING OF THE “CAlRO."
div.p: NOTHING SAVED FROM VESSEL.

The inquiry into the circuinsUnoes attend­ing the straudiug of the Florio-Rubattino 8J3. “Cairo,” which is being held at the Italian Consulate at Alexandria, is oonfined to deter­mining the responsibility for the catastrophe. The enquiry will be concluded to-morrow or the day after. Captain De Marchi has sent in his report

M. Novelli, the Italian tragedian, who was to have appeared at the Zizinia last night, has brought an action in the Italian Consular Court against the Florio-Rubattino Steam Navigation Company for tbe loss occasioned him. Ha. is asking for 300,000 francs compensation. The great actor’s dlecta were not insured.
Nothing has as yet been recovered from the vessel except a few effects, which have been cast into the sea by the foroe of the waves breaking over tbe steamer, and some of the mail bags.

We understand, that the Captain alleges that he is not responsible. He noticed a craft when drawing near the Boghaz Pass very like the pilot’s boat, and be made for it after having’ signalled, fully believing that it contained the pilot. When he was olose up to it ho reoogniaed that it was not the pilot's boat and then turn­ed the ship's head round.

Immediate rue lsurea have been taken by the General Pint Office in order to save as much as possible of the* mails carried by the S.8. “Cairo.” As, however, these mails have been greatly damaged by sea water, the Post Office will do its utmost to dry and deliver them by to-day.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive received yesterday morn­ing the Count de Serionne, M. E. Ghika, Roumanian Ambassador at Vienna ; Graf von Wedel, who presented Professor Kirohner; Sheikh Goneim, and M. Selim Anhonry; who presented his Highness with a copy of his book entitled “Ayat el Aar.”
In the afternoon, his Highness received H. * H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, Mr! Beliufaute Ostborg, and M. Geunadis.

Last night his Highness gave a farewell dinner to Major-General 81ade, C.B., to which were invited the Ministers, Lord Cromer, thd personnel of H. B. M.’s Agency, and the prin­cipal c-fficereof the Army of Occupation.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: I *

A telegmm from Tor yesterday states that the Ottoman S.S. “Bassour&h" has arrived there from Jeddah with 957 Turkish pilgrims bound for Constantinople. Three deathsoccurredduring the voyage from Jeddah.

div.head: BANKING DEVELOPMENTS.
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent writes under ilato of Monday last:—M. Mosevius, sub-manager of the National Bank of Athens, and M. Valaoriti, sub-manager of the agency in this city of the Orient Bank, left last Friday for Salonika, where another branch office of the bank is to be established. I understand that they will leave afterwards for Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: A CAIRO NUISANCE.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes : — Cannot something be said or done to abate the great­est nuisance and offence of Cairo, the donkey- boys to wit 1 The shoeblacks, match-sellers, and others are improving daily ; we are no louger pestered except by isolated specimens; and those have the excuse of extreme youth and its consequent impishness. But your donkey boy‘is a real plague. He is usually an "adult," of a very low class, and up Jo the eyes steeped in vice ; that we all know, we need not enlarge thereon. Happily one does not need to pause and hear what “induce­ments” he has to offer for one’s patronage : but he should surely be absolutely forbidden (as is now largely the case at Meoa House) to accost or speak to people l for in this he is our "béte noire." It is impossible to walk quietly past a group of donkey-boys without “Coming, sarr, nioe donkey, sarr,” and much more howled at one, or to stop a moment without excitibga general charge. No reproof has any effebt un­less it be to bring a flow of filthy language. I speak for the residents more than tor visitors. We may not hit.them (they knowthatl) and we most of us cannot waste our time by calling the attention of the nearest policeman. They (the boys) know perfectly well who is resident and who is not, aud I am certain they take a pleasure iu annoying us. Besides, the tone of voice—as if they had been our trusted guides since infancy in every kind of vioe—is an insult How often has it not infariated me when walking peacefully along the streets 1 As if I wanted to ride a donkey, or as if I hadn’t a tongue in my head, or a pair of eyes, to speak and choose for myself as I would a cab. I appeal to the authorities : it would be so easy to give a general order that none ol these people are to acoost passers ; they are all numbered, all have their regular stands aud ranks. Almost always a "shawish” is somewhere within reach ; and if one or two examples were made, we should soon find the Cairo streets peaceful.

div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Qeissenstein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrei; Station, Liens (reached from Venise or Trieste). Bracing air. Good Mountaineering centre, Tennis. Fishing. Best June, September. Apply Proorietor
